proof:
Let us consider a configuration $F \in \Omega_C^{\mathrm{dis}}$. For such a configuration, its size is bounded by $|F| \le \eta|E_C|$, which implies that its weight is bounded by $w_C(F) \le q^{n_C} (e^\beta - 1)^{\eta|E_C|}$. The cardinality of the set $\Omega_C^{\mathrm{ord}}$ is at most $|\Omega_C^{\mathrm{ord}}| \le 2^{|E_C|}$, and because $F = E_C$ is a valid configuration, we can establish a lower bound for the partition function, $Z_C \ge q(e^\beta-1)^{|E_C|}$. With high probability, the number of edges satisfies $|E_C| \le \frac{dn}{2} + \eta n$, and therefore $|\Omega_C^{\mathrm{ord}}| \le 2^{n(d/2+\eta)}$. By combining these inequalities and using the condition that $\beta \ge \beta_1$, we can bound the ratio as follows:
$$
\frac{Z_C^{\mathrm{ord}}}{Z_C} \le \frac{2^{(d/2+\eta)n}q^{n_C}(e^\beta - 1)^{-(1-\eta)|E_C|}}{q} \le q^{n-(1-\eta)(2+1/10)|E_C|}.
$$
From Lemma 39, we have the high-probability lower bound $|E_C| \ge \frac{dn}{2} - 2ne^{-d/3}$. Substituting this into our expression yields:
$$
\frac{Z_C^{\mathrm{ord}}}{Z_C} \le q^{n[1-(1-\eta)(2+1/10)(d/2-2e^{-d/3})/d]} \le q^{-n[1/20-2\eta+5e^{-d/3}/d]}
$$
Due to the choice of $\eta$, this expression is at most $q^{-n/40}$ for all sufficiently large $d$. Consequently, for any sufficiently large $q$, the ratio is at most $e^{-n}$.
